Is it necessary for a woman to cover her face in the presence of strangers%0D%0A(who are not her designated Mahaarim) according to Shari%E1h?%0D%0A%0D%0AThis question is answered in this article in the context of the claim that%0D%0Athe veil or Niqaab is primarily 'a social requirement and custom according%0D%0Ato the environment and custom and according to the environment and customs%0D%0Aof a particular country.' In endeavouring to answer the question, we will%0D%0Aconfine ourselves to a brief examination of the relevant Qur%E3nic verses.%0D%0A%0D%0ASurah An-Nur, Verses 30 and 31%0D%0A'And Say to the believing women to lower their gaze (from looking at%0D%0Aforbidden things), and protect their private parts (from illegal sexual%0D%0Aacts) and not to show off their adornment except only that which is apparent%0D%0A(like both eyes for necessity to see the way, or outer palms of hands or one%0D%0Aeye or dress like veil, gloves, head-cover, apron), and to draw their veils%0D%0Aall over Juyubihinna (i.e. their bodies, faces, necks and bossoms) and not%0D%0Ato reveal their adornment except to their husbands, or their fathers, or%0D%0Atheir husband's fathers, or their sons, or their husband's sons, or their%0D%0Abrothers or their brother's sons, or their sister's sons, or their (Muslim%0D%0Awomen) (i.e. sisters in Islam), or the (female) slaves whom their right%0D%0Ahands possess, or old male servants who lack vigour, or small children who%0D%0Ahave no sense of feminine sex. And let them not stamp their feet so as to%0D%0Areveal what they hide of their adornment. And all of you beg Allah to%0D%0Aforgive you all, O believers, that you may be successful'%0D%0A%0D%0AIt is apparent that upon a plain reading the purpose of the verse is to%0D%0Aeradicate promiscuity, fornication and adultery and all the preliminary%0D%0Asteps that lead directly to the commission of such shameful acts. The%0D%0Areferences to 'lowering their gaze', 'drawing their veils over their bosoms'%0D%0Aand 'striking their feet to draw attention' indicate that all acts or%0D%0Aomissions which, in the ordinary course leads directly to sexual promiscuity%0D%0Aand FITNAH are forbidden.%0D%0A%0D%0AIn order to totally eradicate sexual promiscuity and FITNAH, the verse goes%0D%0Aon to say that a woman is not permitted to display her beauty and charms%0D%0Aexcept in degrees to her husband, father and the other classes of person%0D%0Aspecified in the verse. The exempt class would constitute the MAHAARIM, and%0D%0Aany other would qualify as strangers or GHAIR MAHRAM. The principle fixed by%0D%0Athe verse is, therefore, that a woman cannot display her beauty to any male%0D%0Aperson other than the persons exempted by the verse. It goes without saying%0D%0Athat the face is the focal-point of a woman's beauty, and the main source of%0D%0Aattraction. Hence, the face of a woman cannot be displayed or shown to a%0D%0Astranger in normal circumstances whether in public or private according to%0D%0Athe general principle fixed by the verse as stated above. She is permitted%0D%0Ato display her beauty to the exempt class (the MAHAARIM) for obvious reasons%0D%0Aof close contact, and because of the considerably lesser danger of sexual%0D%0Apromiscuity and FITNAH within that class. (Zamakhshari)%0D%0A%0D%0AThe Shari%E1h, however, is practical, dynamic and takes into account the real%0D%0Asituations of life. A woman may - in the case of genuine need - be forced to%0D%0Aexpose her face in the presence of strangers. For example, when she appears%0D%0Ain court to give witness, etc.%0D%0A%0D%0AIt is against this background that the preceding portion of the verse 'they%0D%0Ashould not display their beauty and charms except what must ordinarily%0D%0Aappear unavoidable' falls into proper perspective. The words 'Illaa maa%0D%0Adhahara min'haa' are in context an exception to the general rule, and cover%0D%0Athose cases of genuine need and necessity when a woman is forced to expose%0D%0Aher face in the presence of a stranger. That is how the great commentators%0D%0Aof the Noble Qur%E3n have interpreted the verse.%0D%0A%0D%0ATake the following two examples,%0D%0A'Women must not display any part of their beauty and charms to strangers%0D%0Aexcept what cannot possibly be concealed.' (Ibn Katheer)%0D%0A%0D%0A'Why is the woman permitted to display her external beauty and charms?%0D%0ABecause to conceal that would cause her inconvenience. A woman is forced to%0D%0Adeal in commodities with her own hands. She is compelled by genuine need to%0D%0Aexpose her face especially at the times of giving evidence, litigating in%0D%0Acourt and marriage. She is compelled to walk the streets and expose her%0D%0Afeet, especially poor women. This is the meaning of 'illaa maa dhahara min'%0D%0Ahaa' that is 'except what the situations of ordinary life compel her to%0D%0Aexpose'. (Zamakhshari)%0D%0A%0D%0AA further point is the interpretation of 'illaa maa dhahara min'haa' has%0D%0Abeen highlighted by the well known scholar, Moulana Ashraf Ali Thanwi (RA).%0D%0AHe states that the verb used is that of the first form 'dhahara' and not%0D%0A'adhhar' which (in fourth form) signifies a deliberate exposure or display.%0D%0AThe use of 'maa dhahara' indicates that the exposure of the face is confined%0D%0Ato need. (Imdaadul Fataawa vol. 4 p. 181)%0D%0A%0D%0AIt follows from the aforegoing that upon a proper interpretation of the%0D%0Averse the face and hands of a woman can only be exposed to strangers in a%0D%0Asituation of genuine need where concealment would cause her serious%0D%0Ainconvinience. However, genuine need is not open to wide interpretations.%0D%0A%0D%0ASURA AL-AHZAAB - VERSE 53%0D%0A'.And when you ask them for anything you want, ask them from behind a%0D%0Ascreen.'%0D%0A%0D%0AThe meaning of this verse is clear: the companions of the Holy Prophet%0D%0A(Sallallaahu %C1layhi Wasallam) were ordered to communicate with the wives of%0D%0ARasulullah (Sallallaahu %C1layhi Wasallam) from behind a screen and not%0D%0Adirectly face to face. It is obvious that this instruction is not limited to%0D%0Athe wives of the Holy Prophet (Sallallaau %C1layhi Wasallam). The verse has%0D%0Ageneral application and the fact that the noble wives of Rasulullah%0D%0A(Sallallaahu %C1layhi Wasallam) are specifically mentioned emphasises the%0D%0Aimportance of the subject matter. The distinguished jurist, Abubakar Jassas%0D%0A(RA) in his Ahkaamul Qur%E3n states:%0D%0A%0D%0A'This order, although revealed specifically in relation to the Holy Prophet%0D%0A(Sallallaahu %C1layhi Wasallam) is general in application because we are%0D%0Aordered to follow him.' Similarly, the well known commentator of the Noble%0D%0AQur%E3n Imaam Qurtubi (RA) in his Al-Jamia li Ahkaamul Qur%E3n states:%0D%0A'All women are in effect covered by the terms of the verse which embraces%0D%0Athe Shar%E9e principle that the whole of a woman is '%C1wrah' (to be%0D%0Aconcealed) - her body and voice, as mentioned previously. It is not%0D%0Apermissible to expose those parts except in the case of need, such as the%0D%0Agiving of evidence.'%0D%0A%0D%0ASURAH AL-AHZAAB - VERSE 59%0D%0A'O Prophet! Tell your wives and your daughters and the women of the%0D%0Abelievers to draw their cloaks (veils all over their bodies (i.e. screen%0D%0Athemselves completely except the eyes or one eye to see the way).'%0D%0A%0D%0AIn his commentary to this verse, Allama Abubakar Jassas (RA) states the%0D%0Afollowing:%0D%0A'This verse proves that a young woman is ordered to cover her face from%0D%0Astrangers, and to manifest SATR and modesty in public so that doubtful%0D%0Apeople may not be desirous of her.'%0D%0A%0D%0AIt is sufficient to quote the following authentic commentators in their%0D%0Ainterpretation of the verse:%0D%0A'They (women), shall cover their faces and bodies with their outer garment%0D%0Awhen they appear in public for a valid reason.'%0D%0A%0D%0A'They shall cover their faces and.'%0D%0A%0D%0AIbn %C1bbaas states that the Muslim women are ordered to cover their head and%0D%0Afaces with outer garments except for one eye.'%0D%0A%0D%0AAnd Allah Ta%E3la Knows Best.%0D%0A%0D%0AWas salaam%0D%0A%0D%0AMufti Ebrahim Desai
